subsection.title: Before Class
subsection.subsubsection:
Tangent Lines & Secant Lines
Recall that the slope of the line between two points on the curve f(x) is given in a few ways:
\dfrac{\text{rise}}{\text{run}} \qquad \dfrac{y_2-y_1}{x_2-x_1} \qquad \dfrac{f(x_2)-f(x_1)}{x_2-x_1}
Tangent/Secant Lines Tangent Line Secant Line
The tangent line to a curve f(x) is a line which intersects the curve at only one point. A secant line intersects a curve in at least two points.
Here is a brief illustration of a tangent line and a secant line.

subsubsection.title: Velocity
subsubsection.p:
Suppose we want to find the average velocity of an object. We can use the same approach as we did above to find this. The average velocity of an object is given by
v_{avg} = \dfrac{\text{change in position}}{\text{change in time}}

question.statement: What connection might exist between v_{avg} and the work we did in the previous exercises?

question.statement: In the previous example, what do you think the purpose was of looking at so many average velocities?
question.solution: We want to get a better idea of how the velocity changes as we look at smaller and smaller intervals.
